BriefingText:
BRIEFING

You are in a circular 100 km by 120 km orbit around the moon.

This lesson will focus on the two radars onboard, the Landing Radar (LR) and the Rendezvous Radar (RR).

During the landing phase and subsequent rendezvous phase, the LM uses radar navigational techniques to determine distance and velocity. Each phase uses a radar designed specifically for that phase. Both radars inform the astronaut and the computer concerning position and velocity relative to acquired target. During lunar landing, the target is the surface of the moon; during rendezvous, the target is the Command Module.

In this lesson, we will learn how to operate them.
Description: The radars are an important tool used by the Lunar Guidance Computer, as well as other navigation equipment to land on the Lunar surface, or dock with the Command Module after the Lunar Ascent. In this lesson, we will take a brief look at them.

MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to the Lunar Radars lesson! In this lesson, we will learn about the Landing Radar and the Rendezvous Radar.
I recommend you to read the Mission Briefing in the Mission Pad before continuing the lesson.
Before diving into the panels, let's take a look at the two radars.
The Rendezvous Radar (RR), operated in conjunction with a RR transponder in the CSM, is used to acquire and track the CSM before and during rendezvous and docking.
When the Rendezvous Radar is active and the PGNS is in control, the RR provides the PGNS and the cabin displays with line-of-sight (LOS) data with respect to the CSM.
This data is the range and range rate data, and LOS angle and angle rate data. The LOS (line-of-sight) is the line between the RR antenna and the RR transponder in the CSM.
The RR can also track the CSM during the descent to supply tracking data for any required abort maneuver.
The Landing Radar on the other hand provides the PGNS and the astronauts with range and velocity data for control during the descent to the lunar surface.
Using the Landing Radar (LR), the PGNS calculates control signals for the LM rate of descent, hovering at low altitudes and landing.
The Powered Descent usually starts at about 50.000 feet above the Lunar Surface. At this point the Landing Radar is activated, but the computer calculates the altitude.
Once the lunar surface is in range, the Landing Radar (LR) takes over and is active until touchdown.
In the nominal descent trajectory, slant range data are available to the PGNS at approximately 40,000 feet, and velocity data at approximately 35,000 feet.
For more information, I recommend you to check the RADAR chapter in the Reentry - Lunar Module Flight Manual.
Let's take a look at how we can operate these radars. We will start with the Rendezvous Radar. Jump into the Lunar Module.
To function, the RR needs to be locked on to the CSM RR transponder. Once locked on, it will try to track the transponder as best as it can.
To get a lock on, the RR can either automatically search for it by sweeping, or the astronauts can manually control it.
The controls for the RR is located in the RENDEZVOUS RADAR section on Panel 3. The RR selector switch is used to select the mode of operation.
If manual control is preferred, you first use the SLEW mode to manually find the tracking signals, and once the NO TRACK light extuingishes, the mode is set to AUTO TRACK.
The manual slew controls are by default set to CTRL + Arrow Keys. If the mode is set to LGC, all of this is automatic.
Anyways, let's get back to the more practical part of this lesson.
We are currently in orbit around the Moon. Open the Mission Pad and check the Lunar Map.
If you are in the Lunar Module, jump back into the Command Module.
From the Command Module, open the Mission Pad->Map and check your Ap and Pe data.
The Map View shows your Ap and Pe positions on the map.
The long lines are used to easier be able to see them and at what longitude on the surface the orbit points are located.
Now that we know what our orbit is, we can undock the Lunar Module. We will dive deeper into undocking in the next lesson, so for now we will just do it directly.
Still inside the CSM, ensure the LM PWR is set to OFF, and ensure the hatch is closed.
Double check this again, then use the attitude thrusters to align the CSM/LM to prograde, pitch 0, roll 0, and yaw 0. The RCS system for both the CSM and LM is set up to manual control.
When in attitude, find the protected leftmost switch in the group named DOCKING PROBE on the upper part of Panel 2, open it's cover, and set it to EXTD/REL
This released the Lunar Module, and you are slowly drifting apart.
Fire the reverse thrusters for 0.5 seconds to increase the distance slightly, then jump back into the Lunar Module.
Inside the Lunar Module, use its attitude thrusters to maneuver it prograde, and then find the CSM so it's visible through the windows.
Go to the External View to see the Lunar Module. The RR is located on the forehed of the LM roof, facing the forward direction of the LM.
Let's power up the RR. Jump back inside the LM cockpit and look for the AC BUS A - RNDZ RDR circuit breaker on Panel 11, and close it.
Verify that the PGNS - RNDZ RDR is closed as well.
Jump back out to the external view and look at the RR. Then press CTRL + Arrow Keys to slew it around.
Notice that the RR is responding to your input.
When you are done playing, go back inside the Lunar Module and take a look at FDAI 1.
You can set the error needles to point in the direction of the shaft and trunion of the RR. Set RATE/ERROR MON to RNDZ RDR.
The error needles will now show the direction of the radar. Try to center it again, so the error is 0 pitch and 0 yaw.
Now comes the hard part. Try to manually slew the RR so that the NO TRACK light extinguishes. Once this happens, set the RR mode to AUTO TRACK.
When aquired, the X-Pointer will show you the angular difference between the LM body axis (forward) and the LOS.
If you null this, by maneuvering so the X-Pointer lines are crossed in the center, you are looking directly at the CSM transponder.
Set the RNG/ALT MON switch to RNG/RNG RT. The TAPE instruments will now show the range to the CSM transponder, and the range rate. You can now use this to know where and how far the CSM is.
The X-Pointer is a multi-purpose instrument. Notice that when you have the RATE/ERR MON switch to RNDZ RADAR, the ELEV RT and AZ RT placards are illuminated, meaning the angular difference as seen.
The setting of each X-POINTER SCALE switch determines the scaling and whether the X.1 or X1.0 placarding on the associated indicator is illuminated.
When it comes to the electrical requirements, the PGNS - RNDZ RDR powers the radar, while the AC power is used by the motors to drive the radar.
I think this covers the Rendezvous Radar. Let's change gears and take a look at the Landing Radar (LR).
The Landing Radar (LR) is mainly used during the powered descent and landing, and is at the bottom of the descent stage.
The LR provided velocity and range data to the LGC. Forward and lateral velocity data and the slant range and vertical velocity (range rate) data is displayed on the LM panels.
It can have two positions. Position 1 is used during descent, while Position 2 is used during hovering. This tilts the radar accordingly.
The Landing Radar has heaters used to maintain temperature. It's controlled by the HEATERS: LDG RDR, and is closed for the entire mission.
LR antenna temperature is monitored by setting the TEMP MONITOR selector switch to LDG and observing the TEMP indicator for an indication within the operating temperature range of +50 to +150 F.

Most of the operation of the landing radar is otherwise automatic. We will come back to it during the Powered Descent tutorial, but let's dive into its modes of operation, from a theoretical perspective.

The ALT and VEL lights on the LGC illuminates when the radar data is out of bounds. Once extinguished, V57 can be used to let the LGC know that the LR data should be used, instead of the state vector.
In addition, the X-Pointer will show the forward and lateral velocities. To see this data, RATE/ERR MON must be set to LDG RDR/CMPTR.
In this position, the FWD VEL and LAT VEL placards on the X-Pointer illuminates, and it's showing your body velocity relative to the ground.
This is mostly used during P66, when searching for a landing point. It's important that these needles are centered before touching down, meaning you have no forward or lateral velocity.
When these are centered, you can look at the ALT and ALT RANGE tape intruments to slowly bring the Lunar Module down for a soft landing.
To see this information, the RNG/ALT MON switch must be set to the ALT/ALT RT position.

The Landing Antenna switch on Panel 3 is used to set the positon of the LR. In AUTO, the LGC will control this. You can override this setting by setting it to any of the two other positions. Set it to HOVER.
This means the radar is casting its rays downwards, used when hovering. Descent gives it an angle, to show correct values when the LM is tilted from it's flight path.
It's been a long lesson. We will use the LR in the next lesson, when we perform a full powered descent.
This concludes this lesson, good job!

Title: Lesson 8 - Radars
